Two weeks ago the daughter
of Charles H. Percy, Republican
candidate from Illinois for the
U. S. Senate, was tragically murdered in the family's suburban
Chicago home.

SC Bookstore Study
May Lead To Boycott
The Hopkins bookstore is the
object of scrutiny by the Student
Council which may lead to an
attempted boycott of the university supported store if the administration does not act on
Council recommendations.
Bill Reinsch, president of the
Student Council, stated that "We
will present a report on the bookstore to the administration later
in the year, and if no move is
made to alleviate the situation,
them we shall plan a boycott second semester."
The Council action follows the
adoption of a nine point report
presented to the group late last
spring. The report stated that
"it is the primary objective of
the Bookstore Committee to effect a change in the Johns Hopkins Bookstore, changing that
organization to a student or student-faculty co-operative."
Mr. Wesley Taylor, the plant
manager, stated the "There is no
justification for this except poor

facilities and service." Taylor
pointed out that the $200,000
renovation of the bookstore
would change this situation. "If
I have any apology to make it
is for the inadequacy of the fa6ilities."
The Council will receive the
Bookstore Committee's report
sometime in November. and will
send copies to the administration. Action on the boycott will
be decided then.
In addition, Council president
Reinsch and Bookstore Committee head Jim Jacobs have
charged that new books are being sold above retail price and
that used books are being sold
at new book prices.
Mr. Charles Vayne, manager
of the bookstore, stated that the
Council has not contacted him
on the question of above retail
price books, and that used books
were sold only "by mistake" at
publisher's retail price.
Plant Manager Taylor stated
that above retail price books
were sold "by error, not policy."
He stated that "We sell always
at the publisher's price." Taylor
pointed out that used books were
bought from the University of
Alabama for 50
less than the
publisher's price, and sold here
to students at 251/, less than the
original price. The difference of
25',4 goes into freight and handling charges, Taylor explained.
Several freshmen had indicated that they received used
books in their book packets this
week. Investigation showed that
a $5.95 price was noted on the
inside of the books, with a marker on the outside indicating it

NEW

YMCA Assoc. Plans
Extensive Program
Simon and Garfunkel, the
bards of the loneliness of the
modern urbanite, will highlight
the Levering Hall Student Association fall program at the Annual Fall Weekend concert October 21.
The SA concert will be held at
Eastern High School. According
to Bob O'Connor, SA president,
Shriver Hall was not large
enough to enable the organization to afford a name group.
The seats this year are on a
reserved basis and cost $2.50 and
$2.75.
The SA will conduct its first,
major event of the year Sunday
with the religious symposium for
freshman orientation. The symposium, "New Directions of Religion in the 20th Century", a
dinner will follow in Levering
118.11.
The panel will consist of Dr.
Stephen E. Ambrose of the history department, and Dr. Joseph
Connelly, assistant pastor of St.
Gregory the Great Church. Also
serving on the panel will be The
Rev. Herbert 0. Edwards, pastor
of the Trinity Baptist Church, as
well as Rabbi Samuel Rosenblatt, adviser to the Jewish Students Association, and the Rev.
Alfred B. Starrett, rector of Emmanuel Episcopal Church. The
dinner will begin at 5:45 p.m.
The SA is planning to initiate
new programs this year, as well
as to expand the old ones. The
cabinet has been organizing an
expanded tutoring program in
conjunction with Dr. Wickwire's
comprehensive tutoring program.
Levering Hall may concentrate
all its efforts on one particular
school and, in a sense "adopt" it.
O'Connor stated that he felt an

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, SEPT. 30, 1966

SDS

imaginative tutoring program
might generate more enthusiasm
among the Hopkins student body.
The cabinet has also discussed
plans to establish a discotheque
in addition to the Room at the
Top coffee house. The present
tentative plans call for its operation on a BYO—basis. Admission will be open only to Hopkins students, faculty and their
dates. The discotheque will be
open on Friday and Saturday
nights.
The Friday Night Movies
Series will be highlighted by a
Hitchcock Festival, featuring
such films as The Birds, and
Psycho. Other films offered include: Lolita, Jules and Jim,
and H. G. Wells' War of the
Worlds.
The Classic and Contemporary
Film Series will present a wide
range of award winning American and foreign films. Among
them are The Hunchback of
Notre Dame, The Passion of Joan
Of Arc, and Through a Glass
Darkly.
Admission to the Wednesday
night films is open only to members of the Levering Hall Student Association. Application for
one or both of these series may
be obtained at the SA office.
The SA also hopes to expand
its seminar and faculty-student
coffee hour programs. Both the
Humanities Seminar, under the
leadership of philosophy major
Bill Benzon, and the Theology
Seminar, under the leadership
of Ed Pettis, Levering Hall's
minary intern, will be operating. The cabinet hopes to conduct an extensive program of
faculty-student coffee hours in
Levering Hall.

Students for a Democratic
Society will hold its first organizational meeting 7:30 p.m.
Tuesday in the City Students'
Lounge at Goucher College.
Prospective freshmen from
Goucher, Notre Dame, Towson
State, Loyola, and Hopkins
are invited.
SDS is a student group
oriented toward progressive
social change, and all interested students and graduate
students, regardless of political beliefs, are very welcome.
For free transportation to and
from Goucher, or for more
information about SDS, call
LE 9-4998, or drop a note in
Box 631, Gilman Hall.

Theater Hopkins, featuring
basically the same format that
filled the house for it last year,
starts the '66-'67 season two
weeks from today with a production of three short, plays by
Fernando Arrabal.
The production will run October 13-16 at the Barn. None of
the three avant garde selections
—Picnic on the Battlefield, The
Two Executioners, and Orison—
have been performed in the Baltimore area before.
Next on director Edward

Art News

Golden's '66-'67 program are two
plays from the American repetoire theater: Eugene O'Neill's
Hughie and Tennessee Williams'
A Perfect Analysis Given by a
Parrot. The twinbill will run De-.
cember 1-4 and 8-11.
In January the theater will
offer William Alfred's modern
version of the Greek Classic
Agamemnon. Spoon River Anthology, a production by Edgar
Lee Masters featuring folk music
and poetry, is billed for March.
The season winds up in May
with another musical production,
as yet unnamed, to be presented
outdoors.
Ticket subscriptions are running ahead of last year, according to Golden, who last week
was named the University's Director of Special Events, replacing John Synodinos.
Interest Increases
"I'm sure that the success we
had last season, our first, accounts for the increased interest
this year," Golden said. "Therefore we're keeping our format
much the same.
-Although a large part of our
audience would be satisfied with
avant garde productions all the
time, we need the variety.
"We're still an experimental
theater, however, in the sense
that we're working with plays
and authors who've never been
done in this area.
The cast for Golden's first
production includes Don Hart,
Carolyn Stayer, Doris Crane,
Arthur Laupes, Dee Stephens,
Auggie Dorsett, Andrian Callaghan and Dick Weissman,
Tony Mazzaro handles sets,
David Rogers lighting and Linda
Chermock script.

Don'tBypass'Bypass'
Occasionally
communication
does occur in our society, and,
curiously enough, there is an
opportunity for students on the
Hopkins scene to experience this
feeling at the Baltimore Museum
of Art.
Offering something to nearly
every
person's tastes, from
movies to chamber music to all
sorts of the visual art, Old Masters to Op Art, it is a very inexpensive method by which culture
and enjoyment may be transmitted to anyone.
Highlighting the present exhibits presented by the museum
is the Robert and Jane Meyerhoff collection, a distinctively
vibrant and colorful group of
paintings of the 1950's and
1960's. Especially noteworthy are
the works of Robert Rauschberg,
"Archive" and "Bypass", in
which his use of silk screen and
collage are extremely effective.

The Meyerhoff collection began
on Wednesday, Sept. 28, and will
run for four weeks.
To those interested in chamber music, there will be a series
of five concerts to be held on
Sunday afternoons at 3:30 P.M.
in the auditorium of the museum. The opening concert on October 23 will feature the Trio
Flauto Dolce and Jean Hakes,
soprano, in a program of baroque
music by Bach, Vivaldi, Telemann and others.
Tickets for the first concerts
may be obtained by subscription
at the price of ten dollars for
the entire series (six dollars for
students), or singly for $2.75 each
at The Music Centre Concert
Bureau, 1126 N. Charles St., Baltimore 21201.
A film series opening with
Adolph Mekas's "Hallelujah the
Hills," the prize-winning expeoration of the cinema of the
absurd, is open to all members
of the museums. Beginning on
ctober 4 at 8:15 P.M. in the
museum auditorium, the series
contsists of seven presentations,
including two perceptive movies
by the late James Agee, "The
Quiet One" and "In The Street."
Membership in the museum is
five dollars for all full-time students and also offers invitations
to member's previews of new exhibitions, rental of original
works, various museum publications, and many other services.

you, at the Gatehouse on the
south end of campus, where

Concrete Issue
The Orientation of the Class of 1970 was by every
measure the, most poorly planned and ineptly executed
operation since Mussolini invaded Ethiopia.
Once again we were treated to the ludicrous sight
of the campus rhinos charging about the quadrangles
kicking up dust in the faces of the innocent frosh and
greasing each others hoofs in anticipation of a successful season of dirty rush.
The major objection to such behavior is that the
only freshmen who get oriented are prospective members of the herd. Since the prospective members are
already junior rhinos they are in about as much need
of an introduction to the power structure as Lyndon
Johnson. The remainder of those attending didn't learn
anything at all and we do not think it unfair to add
that the best of the current lot of freshman doubtlessly
demonstrated their good taste and judgment by ignoring the whole petty business.
We are quite positive that the higs charged with
the task of shepherding the frosh through their first
week at Hopkins never came close to introducing the
things that are really at issue here. If the News-Letter
had been given the job the first stop on any tour would
have been a close look at the red, white, and blue billboard at the south end of campus. It is a perfect means
toward initiating an illuminating discussion of athletics
S. reality at Homewood.
Gilman Hall was the first major building on the
Hopkins Campus. For years it was the only place where
students could meet and talk without having to endure
the rigors of a half hour in the Levering Cafeteria.
Then the University built the Eisenhower Library and
everyone moved over there. Although the new Library
is an architectural abomination it is harmless in character.
Shortly after the completion of the new Library
the University built a new classroom building. In this
case it approved a design that is so oppressively ugly
as to defy critical description. Soon the Humanities
students were shooed away from Gilman Hall and banished to the new classroom building along with the Administration of the Evening College (or the McCoy
Now, as we see by the sign on the lot, they are
renovating old Gilman Hall. In this case they are not
trying to make a new building look old as with the
Library or a new building look terrible like the new
classroom building, they are taking our only link with a historical and aesthetic past and turning it into what
promises to look like a gigantic tiled bathroom in Lefrack City, Long Island.
Norman Mailer has written that:
"The essence of totalitarianism is that it
beheads. It beheads individuality, vaiety, dissent, extreme possibility, romantic
faith, it blinds vision and deadens instinct; it obliterates the past. It makes factories look like college campuses or
mental hospital's."
Need we add that it makes college campuses look
like factories and mental hospitals as well.
A University which has no regard for the past is
in no way of value to a student seriously interested in
making his way in a society which has misplaced the
alues which might have most aided him. For "the totalitarian impulse not only washes away distinctions but
looks for a style in the buildings .. which diminish
one's sense of function and reduce one's sense of reality ... by dislocating us ... by leaving us further isolated in the empty landscape of psychosis." "A good
school" says Mailer, "can survive in a conVerted Cow
Barn."
Need we remind you that that was exactly the location of the Johns Hopkins News-Letter before the inasion of the numbers.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, SEPT. 30, 1966

Simon and
Garfunkel
Simon and Garfunkel, the internationally known folk-rock duo
whose records consistently hit
the top of the charts, appear in
this year's Big Fall Weekend concert. Sponsored by the Student
Association, Hopkins YMCA, the
concert is slated for October 21st
in the Eastern High School auditorium.
A new and significant trend in
the bourgeoning popularity of
folk music on the American musical scene has been the advent
of the urban folk singer—the citybred youngster who sings of the
unique joys and trials of life in
the megapolis; the alienation, the
the excitement, the loneliness, the
joys that are peculiar to and so
much a part of life in the Big
Town.
And in the realm of urbanoriented folk music, no new act
has caused such excitement as
the fine new duo, Simon and
Garfunkel whose first Columbia
LP, "WEDNESDAY MORNING,
3 A.M." has clearly marked them
as a vital new force on the folk
scene.
Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel,
who write and arrange most of
their own material, sing of life
today. Their first hit, "The
Sounds of Silence," deals with
the problems of communication.
So, too, does their current release, "Dangling Conversation."
In "I am a Rock" they speak of
self-willed alienation. Loneliness
is portrayed against a variety of
backgrounds: apartment house

1

SIMON AND GARFUNKEL
living ("A Most Peculiar Man"),
business
("Homeward
show
organized
religion
Bound"),
("Blessed"). They reflect on the
frustrations experienced by both
the haves and the have nots in
"Richard Cory."
In October of -1964, they
walked into the New York headquarters of Columbia Records
and two weeks later were recording their first LP for that label.
Both still in their early twenties, they have a unique under-

standing of the soul of a young
city dweller, which they are able
to communicate with unusually
effective intensity and audience
appeal.
Simon, who does most of the
writing, and Garfunkel view pop
music as a medium which is just
currently reaching its potential
for making some comment about
the world in which we live to
a large audience.
Tickets for the concert can be
purchased at the Y office in
Levering Hall for $2.75 and $2.50.

By HENRY HOCHERMAN
The Big Question at Homewood this year is who is going to
be president when Dr. Eisenhower retires? Who is going to
take the helm of the academic
ship of state? Amid the frenzied
maelstrom of speculation this
week, many esteemed names
have been bandied about, and it
is possible that Dr. Eisenhower
will once again assume his role
as Republican Kingmaker. Indeed, many of the names mentioned have been those of members of the G.O.P. hierarchy.
Nixon, Scranton, Romney, the
great names of the sixties, are
all in the forefront, and the entire Hopkins community is eagerly holding its breath in anticipation, and wondering, Who
will it be?
In the midst of all this speculation the News-Letter would
like to offer its candidate for
this esteemed office, and to provide, as it has in the past, the
voice of sanity amidst the braying of Jackels.

must be, first and foremost, an

prestige, prestige

have all the attributes one seeks
in a man worthy of the presidency, not of the University, but of
this great nation. He must be a
winning personality. To this end,
the News-Letter puts forth as
its candidate the Great Kansas
Sunflower, Alf Landon.

indeed, a president's president.

the undergraduate community
take up the Landon banner. You
have nothing to lose but your

Trophy Winners
Phi Sigma Delta copped the
fraternity trophy for the second
straight season; Royce house
wrapped up the upperclass trophy pretty early in the spring
competition; and Baker won the
freshman house trophy in a very
tight league all season.

Faced with a season of pro-'
spects cloaked in ambiguity, Alex
Setir opens his coaching career
at Johns Hopkins tomrrow by
taking his thin but enthusiastic
varsity football team to a 2:00
P.M. home opener with Franklin
and .Marshall.
With only four seniors departing from last year's 1-6-1 aggregation and a sizable crew of
sophs coming up from a strong
freshman group, depth might
have appeared to be the least
of Sotir's worries, but the disappearances of several first-line
players whittled his turnout. to
twenty-seven.
Most notable among the absences are those of five '65
starters—tackles Bill Hunt and
Art Peinado, end Bill Nickel,
setback Henry Schaefer, and
wingback Wally Siggers. Also,
soph pass catchers John Cardillo
and John Gorczyk, plus halfback Dan Contesti, are not
present.

SC Bookstore Study
May Lead To Boycott
The Hopkins bookstore is the
object of scrutiny by the Student
Council which may lead to an
attempted boycott of the university supported store if the administration does not act on
Council recommendations.
Bill Reinsch, president of the
Student Council, stated that "We
will present a report on the bookstore to the administration later
in the year, and if no move is
made to alleviate the situation,
them we shall plan a boycott second semester."
The Council action follows the
adoption of a nine point report
presented to the group late last
spring. The report stated that
"it is the primary objective of
the Bookstore Committee to effect a change in the Johns Hopkins Bookstore, changing that
organization to a student or student-faculty co-operative."
Mr. Wesley Taylor, the plant
manager, stated the "There is no
justification for this except poor

facilities and service." Taylor
pointed out that the $200,000
renovation of the bookstore
would change this situation. "If
I have any apology to make it
is for the inadequacy of the fa6ilities."
The Council will receive the
Bookstore Committee's report
sometime in November. and will
send copies to the administration. Action on the boycott will
be decided then.
In addition, Council president
Reinsch and Bookstore Committee head Jim Jacobs have
charged that new books are being sold above retail price and
that used books are being sold
at new book prices.
Mr. Charles Vayne, manager
of the bookstore, stated that the
Council has not contacted him
on the question of above retail
price books, and that used books
were sold only "by mistake" at
publisher's retail price.
Plant Manager Taylor stated
that above retail price books
were sold "by error, not policy."
He stated that "We sell always
at the publisher's price." Taylor
pointed out that used books were
bought from the University of
Alabama for 50
less than the
publisher's price, and sold here
to students at 251/, less than the
original price. The difference of
25',4 goes into freight and handling charges, Taylor explained.
Several freshmen had indicated that they received used
books in their book packets this
week. Investigation showed that
a $5.95 price was noted on the
inside of the books, with a marker on the outside indicating it

YMCA Assoc. Plans
Extensive Program
Simon and Garfunkel, the
bards of the loneliness of the
modern urbanite, will highlight
the Levering Hall Student Association fall program at the Annual Fall Weekend concert October 21.
The SA concert will be held at
Eastern High School. According
to Bob O'Connor, SA president,
Shriver Hall was not large
enough to enable the organization to afford a name group.
The seats this year are on a
reserved basis and cost $2.50 and
$2.75.
The SA will conduct its first,
major event of the year Sunday
with the religious symposium for
freshman orientation. The symposium, "New Directions of Religion in the 20th Century", a
dinner will follow in Levering
118.11.
The panel will consist of Dr.
Stephen E. Ambrose of the history department, and Dr. Joseph
Connelly, assistant pastor of St.
Gregory the Great Church. Also
serving on the panel will be The
Rev. Herbert 0. Edwards, pastor
of the Trinity Baptist Church, as
well as Rabbi Samuel Rosenblatt, adviser to the Jewish Students Association, and the Rev.
Alfred B. Starrett, rector of Emmanuel Episcopal Church. The
dinner will begin at 5:45 p.m.
The SA is planning to initiate
new programs this year, as well
as to expand the old ones. The

imaginative tutoring program
might generate more enthusiasm
among the Hopkins student body.
The cabinet has also discussed
plans to establish a discotheque
in addition to the Room at the
Top coffee house. The present
tentative plans call for its operation on a BYO—basis. Admission will be open only to Hopkins students, faculty and their
dates. The discotheque will be
open on Friday and Saturday
nights.
The Friday Night Movies
Series will be highlighted by a
Hitchcock Festival, featuring
such films as The Birds, and
Psycho. Other films offered include: Lolita, Jules and Jim,
and H. G. Wells' War of the
Worlds.
The Classic and Contemporary
Film Series will present a wide
range of award winning American and foreign films. Among
them are The Hunchback of
Notre Dame, The Passion of Joan
Of Arc, and Through a Glass
Darkly.
Admission to the Wednesday
night films is open only to members of the Levering Hall Student Association. Application for

The SA also hopes to expand
its seminar and faculty-student
coffee hour programs. Both the
Humanities Seminar, under the
leadership of philosophy major
Bill Benzon, and the Theology

Students for a Democratic
Society will hold its first organizational meeting 7:30 p.m.
Tuesday in the City Students'

Prospective freshmen from
Goucher, Notre Dame, Towson
State, Loyola, and Hopkins
are invited.
SDS is a student group
oriented toward progressive
social change, and all interested students and graduate
students, regardless of political beliefs, are very welcome.
For free transportation to and
from Goucher, or for more
information about SDS, call

Theater Hopkins, featuring
basically the same format that
filled the house for it last year,
starts the '66-'67 season two
weeks from today with a production of three short, plays by
Fernando Arrabal.
The production will run October 13-16 at the Barn. None of
the three avant garde selections
—Picnic on the Battlefield, The
Two Executioners, and Orison—
have been performed in the Baltimore area before.

Golden's '66-'67 program are two
plays from the American repetoire theater: Eugene O'Neill's
Hughie and Tennessee Williams'
A Perfect Analysis Given by a
Parrot. The twinbill will run De-.
cember 1-4 and 8-11.
In January the theater will
offer William Alfred's modern
version of the Greek Classic
Agamemnon. Spoon River Anthology, a production by Edgar
Lee Masters featuring folk music
and poetry, is billed for March.
The season winds up in May

Ticket subscriptions are running ahead of last year, according to Golden, who last week
was named the University's Director of Special Events, replacing John Synodinos.
Interest Increases
"I'm sure that the success we
had last season, our first, accounts for the increased interest
this year," Golden said. "Therefore we're keeping our format
much the same.
-Although a large part of our
audience would be satisfied with
avant garde productions all the
time, we need the variety.
"We're still an experimental
theater, however, in the sense
that we're working with plays
and authors who've never been
done in this area.
The cast for Golden's first
production includes Don Hart,
Carolyn Stayer, Doris Crane,
Arthur Laupes, Dee Stephens,
Auggie Dorsett, Andrian Callaghan and Dick Weissman,
Tony Mazzaro handles sets,
David Rogers lighting and Linda
Chermock script.

Concrete Issue
The Orientation of the Class of 1970 was by every
measure the, most poorly planned and ineptly executed
operation since Mussolini invaded Ethiopia.
Once again we were treated to the ludicrous sight
of the campus rhinos charging about the quadrangles
kicking up dust in the faces of the innocent frosh and
greasing each others hoofs in anticipation of a successful season of dirty rush.
The major objection to such behavior is that the
only freshmen who get oriented are prospective members of the herd. Since the prospective members are
already junior rhinos they are in about as much need
of an introduction to the power structure as Lyndon
Johnson. The remainder of those attending didn't learn
anything at all and we do not think it unfair to add
that the best of the current lot of freshman doubtlessly
demonstrated their good taste and judgment by ignoring the whole petty business.
We are quite positive that the higs charged with
the task of shepherding the frosh through their first
week at Hopkins never came close to introducing the
things that are really at issue here. If the News-Letter
had been given the job the first stop on any tour would
have been a close look at the red, white, and blue billboard at the south end of campus. It is a perfect means
toward initiating an illuminating discussion of athletics
S. reality at Homewood.
Gilman Hall was the first major building on the
Hopkins Campus. For years it was the only place where
students could meet and talk without having to endure
the rigors of a half hour in the Levering Cafeteria.
Then the University built the Eisenhower Library and
everyone moved over there. Although the new Library
is an architectural abomination it is harmless in character.
Shortly after the completion of the new Library
the University built a new classroom building. In this
case it approved a design that is so oppressively ugly
as to defy critical description. Soon the Humanities
students were shooed away from Gilman Hall and banished to the new classroom building along with the Administration of the Evening College (or the McCoy
Now, as we see by the sign on the lot, they are
renovating old Gilman Hall. In this case they are not
trying to make a new building look old as with the
Library or a new building look terrible like the new
classroom building, they are taking our only link with a historical and aesthetic past and turning it into what
promises to look like a gigantic tiled bathroom in Lefrack City, Long Island.
Norman Mailer has written that:
"The essence of totalitarianism is that it
beheads. It beheads individuality, vaiety, dissent, extreme possibility, romantic
faith, it blinds vision and deadens instinct; it obliterates the past. It makes factories look like college campuses or
mental hospital's."
Need we add that it makes college campuses look
like factories and mental hospitals as well.
A University which has no regard for the past is
in no way of value to a student seriously interested in
making his way in a society which has misplaced the
alues which might have most aided him. For "the totalitarian impulse not only washes away distinctions but
looks for a style in the buildings .. which diminish
one's sense of function and reduce one's sense of reality ... by dislocating us ... by leaving us further isolated in the empty landscape of psychosis." "A good
school" says Mailer, "can survive in a conVerted Cow
Barn."
Need we remind you that that was exactly the location of the Johns Hopkins News-Letter before the inasion of the numbers.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, SEPT. 30, 1966

Simon and
Garfunkel
Simon and Garfunkel, the internationally known folk-rock duo
whose records consistently hit
the top of the charts, appear in
this year's Big Fall Weekend concert. Sponsored by the Student
Association, Hopkins YMCA, the
concert is slated for October 21st
in the Eastern High School auditorium.
A new and significant trend in
the bourgeoning popularity of
folk music on the American musical scene has been the advent
of the urban folk singer—the citybred youngster who sings of the
unique joys and trials of life in
the megapolis; the alienation, the
the excitement, the loneliness, the
joys that are peculiar to and so
much a part of life in the Big
Town.
And in the realm of urbanoriented folk music, no new act
has caused such excitement as
the fine new duo, Simon and
Garfunkel whose first Columbia
LP, "WEDNESDAY MORNING,
3 A.M." has clearly marked them
as a vital new force on the folk
scene.
Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel,
who write and arrange most of
their own material, sing of life
today. Their first hit, "The
Sounds of Silence," deals with
the problems of communication.
So, too, does their current release, "Dangling Conversation."
In "I am a Rock" they speak of
self-willed alienation. Loneliness
is portrayed against a variety of
backgrounds: apartment house

1

SIMON AND GARFUNKEL
living ("A Most Peculiar Man"),
business
("Homeward
show
organized
religion
Bound"),
("Blessed"). They reflect on the
frustrations experienced by both
the haves and the have nots in
"Richard Cory."
In October of -1964, they
walked into the New York headquarters of Columbia Records
and two weeks later were recording their first LP for that label.
Both still in their early twenties, they have a unique under-

standing of the soul of a young
city dweller, which they are able
to communicate with unusually
effective intensity and audience
appeal.
Simon, who does most of the
writing, and Garfunkel view pop
music as a medium which is just
currently reaching its potential
for making some comment about
the world in which we live to
a large audience.
Tickets for the concert can be
purchased at the Y office in
Levering Hall for $2.75 and $2.50.

By HENRY HOCHERMAN
The Big Question at Homewood this year is who is going to
be president when Dr. Eisenhower retires? Who is going to
take the helm of the academic
ship of state? Amid the frenzied
maelstrom of speculation this
week, many esteemed names
have been bandied about, and it
is possible that Dr. Eisenhower
will once again assume his role
as Republican Kingmaker. Indeed, many of the names mentioned have been those of members of the G.O.P. hierarchy.
Nixon, Scranton, Romney, the
great names of the sixties, are
all in the forefront, and the entire Hopkins community is eagerly holding its breath in anticipation, and wondering, Who
will it be?
In the midst of all this speculation the News-Letter would
like to offer its candidate for
this esteemed office, and to provide, as it has in the past, the
voice of sanity amidst the braying of Jackels.

Faced with a season of pro-'
spects cloaked in ambiguity, Alex
Setir opens his coaching career
at Johns Hopkins tomrrow by
taking his thin but enthusiastic
varsity football team to a 2:00
P.M. home opener with Franklin
and .Marshall.
With only four seniors departing from last year's 1-6-1 aggregation and a sizable crew of
sophs coming up from a strong
freshman group, depth might
have appeared to be the least
of Sotir's worries, but the disappearances of several first-line
players whittled his turnout. to
twenty-seven.
Most notable among the absences are those of five '65
starters—tackles Bill Hunt and
Art Peinado, end Bill Nickel,
setback Henry Schaefer, and
wingback Wally Siggers. Also,
soph pass catchers John Cardillo
and John Gorczyk, plus halfback Dan Contesti, are not
present.
